MAY97003-d-05-23-97-MNNR.Narrative: WC FAILED TO PROPERLY ALIGN SWITCHES, UNKNOWINGLY RAN THROUGH THEM, AND TOLD OUR CREW TO TIE ON ANDPULL UP SO WE COULD MAKE AN AIR TEST; THEN OUR CARS DERAILED.  PER LETTER ATTACHED FROM WC:  WC WASINVOLVED INDIRECTLY IN THIS INCIDENT.  EMPLOYEES FOR WC HAD SET OUT A TRAIN FOR THE MNNR TO PICK UPAPPROXIMATELY 30 MINUTES PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT.  IN THE PROCESS OF TURNING OVER THEIR TRAIN, THE CREW FAILED TO LINE THE SWITCH PROPERLY AND RAN THROUGH IT.  THE TRAIN WAS THEN GIVEN TO THE MNNR CREWON MNNR TRACKS AND IT WAS WHEN THEY PULLED THE TRAIN AHEAD THAT THE DERAILMENT OCCURRED.  THE TRAINWAS UNDER THE OPERATION OF MNNR EMPLOYEES AND WAS ON MNNR TRACKS AT THE TIME OF DERAILMENT, THEREFORE WISCONSIN CENTRAL WILL NOT BE SUBMITTING A REPORT FOR THIS INCIDENT.NoneNoneNoneNoneNoneNoneNone

97145-d-05-14-97-MNA.Narrative: ON MAY 14TH, 1997 THE BRANSON SCENIC, A PASSENGER TRAIN OPERATING OVER MNA MAINLINE, TIED UP IN THESIDING NEXT TO THE BRANSON DEPOT AT 1605.  THE MISSOURI & NORTHERN ARKANSAS RAILROAD PROVIDES AN ENGINEER AND CONDUCTOR FOR THE BSR.  CONDUCTOR CLAIMS HE LINED THE SIDING SWITCH FOR THE MAINLINE, THELOCKED IT.  SHORTLY AFTER THE CREW TIED UP, BSR MECHANICAL EMPLOYEE ADMITS THAT HE WAS ON OR AROUNDTHE BSR ENGINE - BSRX 83, THE LEAD UNIT FACING TOWARD THE SIDING SWITCH - SOUTH.  HE CLAIMS TO HAVELEFT AT 1630.  HE ALSO ADMITS THAT HE TOOK A BLUE LOCK USED BY BSR MECHANICAL FORCES AND LOCKED IT INTO THE SWITCH LEADING INTO THE SIDING AT BRANSON.  THERE WERE 4 KEYS THAT WOULD OPEN THE LOCK.  BSREMPLOYEE DOES NOT REMEMBER HOW THE SWITCH WAS LINED, DOES NOT REMEMBER LOOKING AT THE TARGET, BUT DOES ADMIT HE PUT THE BLUE LOCK ON THE SWITCH.  HE THEN WENT HOME.  AT 1715 THE COTTER NORTH LOCAL OFTHE 14TH, WAS CALLED TO GO ON DUTY AT COTTER.  ON THE MAINLINE, COTTER 100, WAS THEIR TRAIN WITH 3ENGINES:  MNA 504, MNA 502, MNA 636.  THE MNA 504 WAS THE LEAD UNIT, BUT THEIR TRACK WARRANT HAD THEM RUNNING UNDER THE 502.  THEY HAD 7 CARS WAITING FOR THEM TO GO NORTH, 2 LOADS, 5 EMPTIES.  THE MNA504 WAS RUNNING WHEN THEY GOT THERE, BUT THE OTHER TWO ENGINES HAD TO BE STARTED.  THE TRAIN HAD ALREADY BEEN PUT TOGETHER FOR THEM BY THE PREVIOUS CREW.  THEY DID AN AIR TEST, SET AND RELEASE, WITHNO PROBLEMS.  AT 1720 THEY DEPARTED NORTHWARD.  AT 1835 THEY ARRIVED AT THE TYSON FEEDMILL IN BERGMA

0397-d-05-25-97-BXN.Narrative: ON MAY 25, 1997 AT 9:10 AM THE BXN TRAINCREW WAS IN THE PROCESS OF SPOTTING ACID TANKS WHEN THEY RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE BXN SECTION FOREMAN THAT ANOTHER BXN EMPLOYEE HAD FALLEN OFF A RAIL CAR AND WAS HURT. THEY WERE TOLD TO CUT OFF AND PROCEED TO ALCOA PLANT TO MOVE SOME CARS SO THE AMBULANCE COULD GET TO THE INJURED BXN EMPLOYEE. THE TRAINCREW CUT LOOSE FROM THE ACID CARS AND THE SWITCHMAN SAIDHE TIED UP A BRAKE AND SCOTCHED THE WHEELS OF THE TANK CAR. BXN TRAINCREW MOVED TO ANOTHE CUT OF CARS TO COUPLE INTO THEM. AFTER THE CREW COUPLED INTO THE CARS, THE CREW STARTED MOVING THE CARS. THETWO ACID TANKS WERE ROLLING TOWARD THE TRAIN, UNAWARE OF THIS THE BXN 15 WAS STRUCK, RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO ONE COVERED HOPPER, ONE BXN 15 LOCOMOTIVE, AND TWO TANK CARS. THE BXN ENGINEER WAS INJURED AND TAKEN TO SALINE HOSPITAL, WHERE HE WAS TREATED AND RELEASED.NoneNoneNoneNoneNoneNone

97048-d-05-18-97-ARR.Narrative: PASSENGER 3008 SOUTH WAS BEING OPERATED SOUTHWARD, IN THE FORWARD DIRECTION WITH THE SHORT HOOD TO THE FRONT WHEN THE ENGINEER FELT THAT THE TRAIN WAS NOT REACTING CORRECTLY AND INITIATED AN EMERGENCYAPPLICATION OF THE AIR BRAKES. THE FIREMAN WAS OPERATING THE ENGINE FROM THE SEAT BEHIND THE CONTROL STAND OF THE LEAD LOCOMOTIVE. THE ENGINEER WAS SEATED ON THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE REAR CHAIR. THE LOCOMOTIVE CONSIST WAS BEING OPERATED IN THE THROTTLE 3 POSITION PULLING 286 AMPS AT 23 MPH ON THE MAINTRACK AND WAS ASCENDING AT .01% IN A 10 DEGREE 49 MINUTE RIGHT CURVE. THE ENGINEER WAS SEATED IN THE REAR CHAIR ON THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE CAB. THE AUTOMATIC AIR BRAKE, AT 108 PSI, AND THE INDEPENDENTAIR BRAKE, AT  0 PSI, WERE IN THE FULLY RELEASED POSITION. WHILE THE CONTROLS REMAINED STATIC, THE TRAIN SPEED  BEGAN TO REDUCE ABOUT ONE MPH PER TWO SECONDS UNTIL THE TRAIN SPEED REACHED 17 MPH. AT THAT TIME, THE ENGINEER STEPPED ACROSS THE CAB AND PLACED THE AUTOMATIC BRAKE VALVE IN THE EMERGENCYAPPLICATION. WHILE PROCEEDING SOUTHWARD AT 23 MPH, THE TRAIN BEGAN TO LOOSE SPEED AT THE RATE OF  ABOUT 1 MPH EACH 2 SECONDS. THE ENGINEER FELT A "TUGGING" FROM THE REAR OF THE TRAIN, AND HE PLACED THE TRAIN INTO EMERGENCY USING THE AUTOMATIC AIR BRAKE VALVE. THE EAST RAIL ROLLED TO THE EAST AND ALLOWED THE TRAILING LOCOMOTIVE AND FOLLOWING 9 CARS TO DERAIL. THE LEAD LOCOMOTIVE STOPPED AT MP 331.7. NO INJURIES RESULTED FROM THE DERAILMENT OF THIS EQUIPMENT. THE PROBABLE CAUSES FOR THE EAST RAIL
